title: In 2016 will the Permanent Court of Arbitration rule that China's "nine-dash line" is contrary to the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS)?
preds:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/beijing-remains-angry-defiant-and-defensive-as-key-south-china-sea-tribunal-ruling-looms/2016/07/12/11100f48-4771-11e6-8dac-0c6e4accc5b1_story.html
The Washington Post seems to think so, assuming their quote is accurate:
"The tribunal ruled that 'there was no legal basis for China to claim historic rights to resources ... within the sea areas falling within the "nine-dash line".'"

Just in from The Permanent Court of Arbitration "China has 'no legal basis' to claim historic rights in South China Sea UN Tribunal finds " http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-12/china-no-legal-basis-south-china-sea-tribunal-finds/7622738

Yes. Press release here: https://pca-cpa.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/175/2016/07/PH-CN-20160712-Press-Release-No-11-English.pdf "Accordingly, the Tribunal concluded that, to the extent China had historic rights to resources in the waters of the South China Sea, such rights were extinguished to the extent they were incompatible with the exclusive economic zones provided for in the Convention. The Tribunal also noted that, although Chinese navigators and fishermen, as well as those of other States, had historically made use of the islands in the South China Sea, there was no evidence that China had historically exercised exclusive control over the waters or their resources. The Tribunal concluded that there was no legal basis for China to claim historic
rights to resources within the sea areas falling within the ‘nine-dash line’" More: https://pca-cpa.org/en/news/pca-press-release-the-south-china-sea-arbitration-the-republic-of-the-philippines-v-the-peoples-republic-of-china/ The entire document: https://pca-cpa.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/175/2016/07/PH-CN-20160712-Award.pdf Mirror: http://www.andrewerickson.com/2016/07/pca-press-release-pca-case-no-2013-19-the-south-china-sea-arbitration-the-republic-of-the-philippines-v-the-peoples-republic-of-china/ Devastating verdict for China. No extended maritime zones, no EEZs. The verdict is 500 pages long, but this article is pretty detailed: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/12/philippines-wins-south-china-sea-case-against-china?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other&utm_content=bufferd82b0&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer Better one: http://globalnation.inquirer.net/140947/key-points-arbitral-tribunal-decision-verdict-award-philippines-china-maritime-dispute-unclos-arbitration-spratly-islands-scarborough?utm_content=buffer00064&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer

For the first time in my life, I recently hired an attorney to prepare an advice letter on an issue.  In so doing, I learned many things, one of which is that one must be as careful with attorneys as one is with God with what one asks for, because that's likely what one will get. The attorney answered the question exactly as it was stated, not as it was intended. The more I think about this question, the more concerned I am that the ruling will respond narrowly to the specific issues involved, and not to the larger issue of the validity of the nine-dash line.  This point is well argued by other forecasters.  See posts by @Aches http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/242193 and @lsgold7 http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/266335 A narrow ruling will be less controversial, yet it may indirectly achieve the same ends, as Isgold7 explains. It would be more defendable. It won't make anyone happy, but it won't throw gasoline on hot coals, either. I'd really like to hear from people who think that the ruling will be broad as to why they think so. For 3 months I was at 88%.  I now think that was a huge mistake, one rooted mainly in simplistic, wishful thinking.  I'm flipping my forecast to 12%.

When I read that the Permanent Court of Arbitration may rule on July 7th, I thought I should check my forecast. I have been troubled from the launch of this question about just what GJO will require to be said in the judgment in order to cause this question to resolve as yes.   I don't think that GJO will consider that any/all rulings in favor of the Philippines will necessarily cause this question to resolve as "yes".  I note that many top forecasters are inching their forecasts towards 100%:  why?  Do they think that the delayed ruling suggests a positive outcome?     And, Aches makes some very good arguments about why the ruling might skirt the issue of the nine-dash line altogether.  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/242193 So, I am very conflicted about this question.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

After some research, I'm lowering my forecast to 10 percent.  When it ruled on issues of jurisdiction in November 2015, the Permanent Court of Arbitration decided that it had jurisdiction over half of the claims submitted by the Philippines (including claims 3, 4, 6, 7, 10, 11 and 13), but it reserved consideration of its jurisdiction over the other half (1, 2, 5, 8, 9, 12, and 14) until a later date.  The difference between the two sets of claims is important. The first set, which the Court decided it had jurisdiction over, are primarily technical claims over whether specific features in the South China Sea qualify as islands under Article 121(1) and (2) of UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). While the Court is likely to side with the Philippines on these claims, doing so will not require them to address China’s 9-dashed line.  The claims that the Court reserved judgement on are far more sweeping, including claim (2), which reads: “China’s claims to sovereign rights jurisdiction, and to ‘historic rights’, with respect to the maritime areas of the South China Sea encompassed by the so-called ‘nine-dash line’ are contrary to the Convention and without lawful effect to the extent that they exceed the geographic and substantive limits of China’s maritime entitlements expressly permitted by UNCLOS.” I don't think the Court will (a) find it has jurisdiction to adjudicate this particular claim and then (b) find in favour of the Phillipines.   When China ratified the United Nations Convention on the Laws of the Sea it chose to exclude the application of UNCLOS’s compulsory dispute settlement mechanisms for “disputes concerning the interpretation or application of articles...relating to sea boundary delimitations, or those involving historic bays or titles,” as allowed by Article 298(1)(a)(i). Given this, it seems unlikely the court has jurisdiction to adjudicate claim (2), which deals with historic rights and China's 9-dashed line. It is far more likely to issue a ruling focused on the technical questions in the fist set of claims raised by the Phillipines.   Sources:
(1) UNLCOS Part XV, Settlement of Disputes: http://www.un.org/depts/los/convention_agreements/texts/unclos/part15.htm
(2) China's statement upon ratification of UNCLOS: http://www.un.org/depts/los/convention_agreements/convention_declarations.htm#China%20Upon%20ratification
(3) Case transcripts and media releases: http://www.pcacases.com/web/view/7

Lowering forecast a bit. I found this, from the Maritime Awareness Project, compelling:  "The PCA may disappoint those seeking greater clarity on some issues, however. The arbitrators are likely to avoid certain compelling questions and issue a narrow (and unanimous) decision. For example, the decision is likely to avoid altogether a direct repudiation of the nine-dash line. Although we can expect a ruling that restates that all claims must be “in accordance with UNCLOS and international law,” this language will fall short of taking on the nine-dash line directly. First, exactly what the line demarcates or claims is unclear, which leaves the PCA without any firm legal approach to address it. Second, the nine-dash line will be rejected anyway by implication of the territorial seas associated with the certain features. Although all eyes are fixed on the nine-dash line, the arbitrators likely will stick to the issues (and aforementioned features) at hand, avoid angering China any more than necessary, and deliver a narrow but unanimous ruling" http://maritimeawarenessproject.org/2016/04/27/forecasting-the-south-china-sea-arbitration-merits-award/

In order for China's "nine-dash line" to be congruent with UNCLOS historical effective control must be proven. Though there are some islands within the the area that China has established settlements on, and more recently constructed military bases upon, there is no evidence of continued effective control within the entirety of the 'nine-dash line". The fact that China has declined to participate in the arbitration also decreases the likelihood that the "nine-dash line" will be considered legitimate. If China does not defend their claim then the arbitral tribunal is left to guess at what China's defence would be. The result is a weak defence at best.

I don't suppose there is any hope of getting the Nice People In Charge Here to give us a hint about whether any finding for the Philippines is a Yes.  That would require them to put some thought into the issue.  The question seems remarkably clear for a change, but I no longer trust these people to know what they mean when they say things.  Otherwise I would suppose they meant what the words of the question say.   That would require the Court to say something explicit about the nine-dash line and UNCLOS.  I happen to think the Court will do that; therefore, if they find for the Philippines but don't mention the goddam line, I should be marked Wrong.  Stay tuned.

My impression is that this will be enough to sway the determinators. Plus, the average on this question has moved up to my previous forecast of 90%, so I'm moving a bit to stick on the "yes" side of the mean. Not technically good behaviour (especially given the number of 100% type forecasts) but you don't get points for being right if you're less resolute than the market.

Interesting to see so many top forecasters hovering in the mid-80s. Isn't there some rule of probability that says: "If a bunch of people research different sources, and all think that something will probably happen, add a little extra probability to account for the hypothetical impact of the extra sources"? That's what I'll do here, cutting half the distance to the goal.

With rare exceptions, courts will not rule on an issue that hasn't been presented as part of somebody's argument.  Since the Philippines' argument reportedly doesn't mention the line and China are not presenting an argument, the court can find for the Philippines on the merits of the case with respect to individual rocks, which is probably what will happen.  The Chinese will ignore any ruling anyway, but there is no reason to irritate them gratuitously.
I don't think this arbitration court will have the guts to rule against China. I just don't feel it happening.

After reviewing similar cases (involving application of the UNCLOS) presented before PCA, I concluded that 20% of the cases were terminated prior to hearing, one of the parties withdrawing its motion. And the result for the remainder is usually so that neither party is completely satisfied.

There will almost certainly be a finding for the Philippines in this case, but the Court can achieve that without negating the nine-dash line in terms.  If they choose the narrower path, you can chalk it up to either (a) commendable judicial restraint, in the sense of not issuing a ruling broader than needed to settle the instant issue; or (b) despicable political cowardice, in the sense of not issuing a ruling that will piss off the Chinese.   Nobody thinks the nine-dash line has any standing in international law except as the punchline to an unfunny joke,  but nobody needs to say that out loud, either, at least in an official capacity.

This is trickier than it may appear, I think. In terms of anybody's notion of international law, the nine-dash line is a nonsense.  China expects to lose this case, of course, which is why they've already announced they'll be paying no attention to the ruling.  However, I'm pretty sure the case doesn't require a ruling on the line as such, only on a specific and limited claim.  The Court could rule on that claim and never mention the nine-dash line at all.  In fact, I'm having trouble thinking of how you'd frame a question so that the Court would ever have to rule on the legality of the nine-dash line. The Court could erode the line on a case-by-case, rock-by-rock basis. The Chinese won't care, which sort of takes all the fun out of it, but they may well use any such ruling(s) as an excuse to step up their incursions in that part of the world.  Coming down some, but perhaps not far enough if by any off-chance I'm right about this.

PCA does not rule in 2016 2% -  all the commentators and the Philippines seem to indicate a decision is imminent, but I can't find anywhere where PCA has committed to make a decision this year - if anyone has seen something to the contrary please let me know. New Philippino president (May elections) withdraws claim: 1% as Grace Poe (favourite according to GJP) has said she would continue arbitration, while only Binay of the other candidates seems likely to even entertain withdrawing claim. PCA rules for China on validity of Nine-dash line: 1% apart from their "historic rights" claim, there seems no legal basis (in fact quite the opposite) for claiming such a wide expanse of ocean (even if all rocks are considered island's the line would be different). Well, the big issue is, what is the nine-dash line supposedly representing? If it's a claim of territorial sea, then it pretty blatantly violates UNCLOS and all pre-UNCLOS international regimes regarding limits on the territorial sea, and accordingly is indisputably invalid, and its age is irrelevant.  It is invalid for the same reasons the similarly old (1946-1950) 200 nautical mile territorial waters claims by Chile, Peru, and Ecuador were and are invalid.  Further, the People's Republic, by ratifying UNCLOS and failing to reserve the territorial claim in its contemporaneous declaration ( http://www.un.org/depts/los/convention_agreements/convention_declarations.htm#China%20Upon%20ratification ), absolutely surrendered it under international law in favor of UNCLOS definitions.  It would also be inconsistent with the territorial sea claims of the PRC in its own laws. If it's a claim of an EEZ, well, EEZs only were formalized by UNCLOS, which means that the 1947 maps are irrelevant; China could not then claim something that did not at the time exist.  Further, a current claim as an EEZ would be invalid under UNCLOS anyway, since it would go well beyond the plausible limits even if every disputed feature was counted as a Chinese island.  China, by failing to even mention this EEZ claim in its declarations, absolutely surrendered it under international law upon ratifying UNCLOS in favor of UNCLOS definitions. If it's merely a claim to the islands/rocks within that limit (the rocks could then have 12-mile territorial waters but no EEZ, while the islands would have EEZs), then UNCLOS can't apply; it doesn't say what land people can claim.  This interpretation would also be the only interpretation of the nine-dash line consistent with the declarations made by China upon ratification, which was only to "all its archipelagos and islands as listed in article 2 of the Law of the People's Republic of China", which includes the Paracel (Xisha) islands, the Zhongsha Islands (of which Scarborough Reef is the largest), and the Spratly (Nansha) islands. I accordingly expect a declaration of invalidity of the line insofar as UNCLOS applies directly, and a ruling that the panel is is incompetent to rule on the validity of the line as a claim to the islands/rocks inside of the line. I also expect that to be scored by GJOpen as the Permanent Court of Arbitration ruling the line as contrary to UNCLOS, because those are the only aspects under which UNCLOS would apply to its validity, but I'm adding some uncertainty since I'm not sure that's how GJOpen would score it. (How the panel will adjudicate the question of which features are underwater, which are valid rocks, and which are valid islands, I have no idea, but think is irrelevant to this question in itself.)

The nine-dash line is a HUGE swath of territory. Upholding nine-dash line totally in favor of China would override long-standing maritime law dealing with Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ). It would marginalize several countries beyond the Philippines (Vietnam, Brunei, Malaysia, and Taiwan) including rights of navigation.  Reading between the lines in the background to this IFP, upholding the nine-dash line for China  would appear to create a  right of countries to lay claim to wider areas of a country's boundaries by laying claim or developing submerged areas. That would seem to benefit the most powerful against the least powerful.  The longer the UN waits to address the territorial issues in the South China Sea will only amplify the disputes and risk for deadly conflict. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:9_dotted_line.png
